data.name: FolkloreBody
data.value: On July 27th, 2014 in Ravnogor was held the Second International Amateur Folklore Festival. It was organised again by Nina Gruncharova, who lives in Stockholm, Sweden. A composite choir "Kuriosa" /guests of the hotel "Boryka"/ participated in the festival featuring singers from Sweden, Finland, Norway and Turkmenistan. The choir is headed by Karin Bjurvald and had Maria Leshkova as a guest-conductor. The soloists performed choral works in Swedish and folklore songs in Bulgarian. They presented typic Bulgarian dances taught by the freelance composer and musician Michail Dinchev. Georg Schubert from Hungary proved his mastery of the bagpipe. In the celebration actively took part the "Folklore Group at the National Cultural Center April 23th, 1876" and the church choir of Ravnogor, the Cultural Centers of Skutare and Rozovo, as well as bagpipers and singers from the towns of Peshtera and Bratsigovo

data.name: LocalityP1
data.value: The village of Ravnogor is located at 1350 metres above sea level in the area of Batak in the north-western Rhodope Mauntains. The peak Sveta Nedelia soars just above it. Climbing up its steep slopes, you can see the magnificent view that reveals. In the west, you can clearly see the village and the entire Ravnogorian plateau with its potato fields and forests. In the north there is the Trakia lowland and in the east and south stretch the Rhodopes. The deeply dug valley of river Vucha is clearly outlined and beyond it there is the mountain of Chernatitza with its peaks Modur and Persenk. The village was established upon the lands of the ancient Thracians, proof of which are the mounds, located in its territory. Its first name dates back from the time of the Ottoman slavery – the village was called Koria (meaning literally ‘forest’) and it gets its name with the acknowledgment of the village as an administrative unit in the Turkish empire in 1777. For the sake of the fact that the Turks did not manage to convert the then inhabitants to Mohammedanism, they called them ‘aksis’ (meaning ‘bad people’), and the village – Aksi Koria.

data.name: LocalityP2
data.value: After the liberation of Bulgaria with a decision of the municipal council the name of the village is changed to Iasu Koria (meaning ‘flat forest’). It was kept till 1934 when by a government decree it is replaced with the current name – Ravnogor (which is the Bulgarian equivalent of ‘flat forest’). At that time the main means of living were field farming and stock-breeding. Oats, rye, peas, vetch, beans, maize, lentil and potatoes were cultivated. Among the animals the biggest importance had goats, horses and cows.

data.name: LocalityP3
data.value: The territory of the village is 92 000 decars. Its frontiers are in the north-east – the lands of the village of Zhrebichko, in the east – the banks of river Vucha, in the south – the lands of the village of Fotinovo, in the south-west – the lands of the village of Nova Mahala, in the south-west – the lands of Rozovo village and the town of Bratzigovo.

data.name: PotatoBody
data.value: Potatoes are the main cultivation in Ravnogor and means of living for the inhabitants. From old times the village is recognized as a centre of eco-production of potatoes for southern Bulgaria. The seed-producing farm which existed here until 1990 and was one of the biggest in Bulgaria has contributed for the good reputation of the local production. At the present moment the village is well-known throughout the country with the ecologically pure potatoes produced here. The celebration exists scarcely from the autumn of 2005 but from now on it will carry out through the last Friday of October. It consists of presentation of potatoes, specific dishes and decoration of them. For the best performed in the categories people there are rewards, too.

data.name: StElenaBody
data.value: at the peak of the same name is set up a chapel where a boiled mutton is cooked. The inhabitants of the village and the guests go there to express their homage or just to go for a walk. It is carried out through the church celebration ‘St. Elena and Konstantin’.

data.name: StIlijaBody
data.value: people celebrate it on the 20th of July or the Saturday before it. The fair takes place alongside of the ‘St. Ilija’ chapel. Everyone lies on the meadow round the chapel and enjoys the Rhodope music and traditions. At this celebration there are a lot of family meetings, a boiled mutton is cooked, people dance traditional folk dances. Since 2014 the festival has evolved into a Bagpipe Contest Ilinden - Ravnogor with participants from all over Bulgaria.

data.name: StPeterBody
data.value: takes place every year on the last Friday of June. The celebration continues for three days – until Sunday and it is filled with various folklore programme and a lively horo/Bulgarian folk dance/ is curving. Guests of the celebration are members of the municipal council, supreme representatives of church and prominent statesmen. The tourists have the opportunity to enjoy the Rhodope traditions and celebration.

data.name: TraditionsGeneral
data.value: The tourists in the village can take part in a series of local customs, more important of which are:

data.name: YouthBody
data.value: takes place on the last Friday of July – It’s a natural continuation of the Soldier’s celebration, when the levis were sent to barrack. The girls and the boys are preparing for a long time for the celebration which lasts for three days and three nights. You can hardly see anywhere else so many youngsters who dance folk dances for 6 – 7 hours uninterruptedly on the square.
